node.text:
From a very early age, African-American civil rights icon and #UnitedNations leader, Ralph Bunche understood the pain and peril of racism.

Yet Bunche turned those experiences into a catalyst for change on the international stage, pursuing a legendary career as one of the most senior diplomatic officials of his time. 

From walking side-by-side with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., to working for peace as a UN mediator in Palestine, watch and learn more about the Nobel Prize Laureate. 

#FightRacism

node.title: Hero for Justice on the World's Stage

node.text:
"Because of climate change we are seeing even more intense storms, rising sea levels and many deaths. But we don’t have to accept this – we can act - and we must act as a matter of justice."

Environmentalist Sunita Narain explains why it's important that all of us #ActNow to achieve the goals of the #ParisAgreement. 

"Every country, rich or poor, is exposed to extreme weather. We need to build better and more resilient infrastructure – from electricity grids to roads, bridges and buildings. All these approaches are set out in the Paris Climate Agreement – adopted by nearly 200 countries. We can do it – we must do it – and we must act quickly."

From recycling to using less energy and water to opting for public transport, each and every one of us can take little steps in our everyday lives that can have a big impact. Tell us in the comments what you are doing to protect our planet.

#ClimateAction #GlobalGoals

node.text:
"We don’t have to choose between using energy and protecting the planet."

@unep Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee explains the role sustainable energy plays in building a better future for all. 
 
"Imagine a world where every job is based on clean, renewable energy – and where wind and solar are even more abundant. And where energy is affordable and reliable – and available to everyone. This might sound like a fantasy – but it’s achievable and we know how to get there."

The #ParisAgreement on the climate emergency is our roadmap for moving to a low-carbon economy and achieving a sustainable future. Since this international #ClimateAction treaty opened for signature 5 years ago, almost 200 countries have signed on to tackle the climate crisis together to limit global warming to protect people and planet.

 #GlobalGoals #ActNow

node.text:
Cities are major contributors to the climate crisis, but also an important hub for #ClimateAction.

@UNEP Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee explains what a green future for cities could look like & how the #ParisAgreement can help us get there.

node.text: Meet @unep Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee. She's a Kenyan engineer taking #ClimateAction and helping to #BeatPlasticPollution by recycling plastic waste into building materials.

node.text:
"My warmest wishes to everyone celebrating #EidAlFitr," #UnitedNations Secretary-General @antonioguterres said on Wednesday.

"I was delighted to mark the end of Ramadan with Asia El-Sayeed Ali, a Yemeni health worker helping malnourished children and mothers in a @worldfoodprogramme-supported nutrition clinic.

Asia personifies core values of Ramadan: compassion and empathy. Her resilience in the face of the devastating conflict in Yemen, as well as her life-saving work in support of people in desperate need have moved me greatly.

As #Ramadan comes to an end, let us continue drawing inspiration from its many lessons of solidarity that are celebrated during this Holy Month."

Regram: @antonioguterres

node.text:
Regram: @antonioguterres

Young people are the most affected by the climate decisions taken today. Their ideas, voices and actions are crucial to deliver meaningful and ambitious #ClimateAction for all.

@pcopaloma and @mahery_loha are two inspiring climate activists who exemplify the leadership and commitment of young people worldwide to address the most challenging problems we face today.

I'm grateful for our discussion and their insights on how to achieve the meaningful participation of youth, women and indigenous peoples as we tackle the climate crisis.

#ActNow #GlobalGoals

node.text:
@unep Goodwill Ambassador @aidanrgallagher describes how the #ParisAgreement can help us create a world free from the threats of the climate crisis. 

"This is personal for me," he explains. "I don’t want to choke on the air I breathe, or see wildfires burning out of control. So let’s keep working together. And you too can protect what is left and repair what has been damaged."

On Thursday's #EarthDay, @antonioguterres will be joining the U.S. Leaders’ Summit on Climate to reiterate his call for urgent #ClimateAction. 

"The Paris Agreement is our pact with our children, grandchildren & the whole human family," said the Secretary-General. 

"The climate crisis is the race of our lifetimes. We must go much further, and much faster."

#GenerationRestoration #ForNature

node.text: On Monday's International Day of Human Space Flight, @europeanspaceagency astronaut @thom_astro became the newest @fao Goodwill Ambassador. He will use his voice and unique perspective from space to advocate for #ClimateAction and to help reduce hunger.

node.title: French astronaut Thomas Pesquet becomes newest @fao Goodwill Ambassador

node.text:
All children have the right to a happy and healthy childhood, free from discrimination and full of love and acceptance. And acceptance begins at home. Every child should grow up in safe, loving and nurturing environment.

No child should suffer because of who they are. All children deserve protection and equal rights. Let's see kids the way they see themselves.

On Wednesday's International Transgender Day of Visibility, join @unaidsglobal in calling for the rights of transgender children to be protected.

#TransDayOfVisibility #SeeMeAsIAm

node.text:
Six years since the start of the conflict, millions of Yemenis are in need of humanitarian assistance. Over four million are displaced within the country. 

Our colleagues from UNHCR, the #UnitedNations Refugees Agency, are in #Yemen providing aid, but they cannot do it alone. 

Please click the link in the @refugees' bio to help. 

#YemenCantWait

node.text:
Maya (@ghazalmia) fled Damascus, #Syria at age 16 and overcame numerous barriers to become the world’s first female Syrian refugee pilot. 

Check out her inspiring story!

#WithRefugees

node.title: Meet Maya Ghazal, the newest @refugees Goodwill Ambassador

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 24, 2021. May be a closeup of 1 person, child, standing and grass.

node.text:
Meet 8-year-old Ágata from #Brazil, who was out of school for an entire year due to the pandemic.

Thanks to an initiative supported by @unicef, and with help from her teachers, the young student re-enrolled and continued learning from home amid the pandemic. "It has been easy and difficult, because sometimes when I'm writing, I forget some of the things the teacher taught me," Ágata explains. 

Due to #COVID19 related school closures, the first day of school remains an aspiration out of reach for 140 million first-time students around the world. The longer students remain out of school, the further they fall behind and the greater the risk of dropping out. 

UNICEF is calling on governments to safely reopen schools for in-person learning as soon as possible, stressing that getting children back into the classroom and providing teachers with the support they need is critical.

Regram: @unicef I 📸: UNICEF/UN0500190/UN0500186/Marques

#ForEveryChild #GlobalGoals

node.text:
#Thailand provides nearly 300 military & police officers to @unpeacekeeping.

#UnitedNations peacekeepers leave their families behind to keep the peace, restore stability, protect civilians and help create conditions under which refugees can voluntarily return home.

They are #ServingForPeace at great personal risk and under harsh conditions to help others, including amid the challenges caused by the #COVID19 pandemic.

👉 Scroll through to see pictures of peacekeepers from Thailand working for the UN peacekeeping mission in South Sudan (@unmissmedia) and the former African Union - UN peacekeeping mission in Darfur (UNAMID).

📸: UNAMID/Albert González Farrán; UNMISS/Gregorio Cunha

#A4P #GlobalGoals

node.text:
Mother Yusleidy and her two sons Axel and Ángel from #Venezuela cuddle in #Ecuador. 

The mother and her children left Venezuela due to a lack of available medical treatment for Axel's life-threatening heart condition. "A doctor told me that the only solution was to find treatment outside the country," explains Yusleidy. 

Although Axel is now being treated, his mother has struggled to find work amid the #COVID19 pandemic. Even before the pandemic, refugees, forcibly displaced people, and the stateless struggled to obtain work permits and get access to formal employment and social safety nets. 

The #UnitedNations Refugee Agency (UNHCR) is working with partners and governments to support families like Yusleidy's by providing emergency shelter, legal assistance and more.

Regram: @refugees I 📷: © UNHCR/Ilaria Rapido Ragozzino

node.text:
#Throwback to September 2019 when our furry colleagues from the #UnitedNations K-9 Unit posed for a picture in front of the giant #UNGA hashtag at UN Headquarters in #NYC.

Monday is #HashtagDay. Here are some of our other favourite hashtags to follow, today and every day:

#GlobalGoals 💡

#StandUp4HumanRights ⚖️

#FightRacism ✋

#ServingForPeace 🕊️

#ClimateAction 🌳 

#BeatPlasticPollution ♻️

#WithRefugees 🤝

#ForMigration 🌍

#HealthForAll 🚑

#ZeroHunger 🍚

#ForEveryChild 👶

#GenerationEquality 👧

📷: UN Photo / Mark Garten

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 22, 2021.

node.text:
The "Ark of Return" at #UnitedNations Headquarters in #NYC is a permanent memorial to honour the victims of slavery and the slave trade.

Designed by an American architect of Haitian descent, the memorial pays tribute to the courage of enslaved people, abolitionists and unsung heroes who helped end the oppression of slavery.

It also reminds visitors of the complete history of slavery, urging them to acknowledge its legacy and to heighten awareness of the current dangers of racism, prejudice and slavery’s lingering consequences.

On Monday's #RememberSlavery Day, we pay homage to the victims of slavery and all who fought the injustice of the slave trade.

📷: UN Social Media / Elif Gulec

#GlobalGoals #FightRacism  #standup4humanrights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
Throwback to 2019 when Angelina Jolie attended a @unpeacekeeping meeting at #UnitedNations Headquarters in #NYC.

For two decades, she has been a fierce advocate for refugees, displaced and stateless people. Now, at a moment when humanitarian crises are spiraling, the @refugees Special Envoy will be sharing her experience here on @instagram.

Welcome to Instagram, @angelinajolie!

📷: UN Photo/Cia Pak

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 21, 2021. May be an image of fire and text that says 'INTERNATIONAL DAY FOR VICTIMS OF VIOLENCE BASED ON RELIGION OR BELIEF AUGUST 22'.

node.text:
Targeting populations simply because of their religion or belief is a human rights violation.

"Across the world, we continue to witness a rise in hate speech, intolerance, and even physical violence and attacks on individuals, groups, and sites, purely because of their religious beliefs or significance," said @antonioguterres on 
Sunday's International Day Commemorating the Victims of Acts of Violence Based on Religion or Belief.

"Let us commit to turning the tide on this appalling trend, to building more inclusive and peaceful societies, where diversity is celebrated as a richness that strengthens us all."

#StandUp4HumanRights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 21, 2021. May be a closeup of flower and nature.

node.text:
Have a look at these flying honey bees collecting pollen from flowers. 

Our very existence depends on bees and other pollinators. They increase food production, give us honey and nutritious food, and are key for helping achieve the #GlobalGoals.

Yet, these guardians of biodiversity are under threat from human activities.

The good news is that we can all help protect bees and support beekeepers by growing native plants, buying raw honey from local farmers, avoiding pesticides and taking #ClimateAction.

On Saturday's #HoneyBeeDay, join us in celebrating the vital role these pollinators play in our lives!

📸: FAO / Zinyange Auntony, Luis Tato, Giada Semeraro

node.text:
UN Deputy Secretary-General @aminajmohammed carried out a two-day mission to #Haiti, following an earthquake that devastated the country last weekend. 

“I saw once again the incredible resilience of the Haitian people who have suffered so much and are now mobilized to support their neighbours and communities in the aftermath of the earthquake,” she said. 

“We stand here in solidarity with Haiti and are in awe at the incredible work the national authorities and the UN agencies are doing to help in these difficult times.” 

📸: UN_OCHA/Matteo Minasi

node.text:
A devastating earthquake has heavily damaged more than one-third of schools in southern #Haiti, just weeks before they were due to re-open.

The massive earthquake has left entire classrooms destroyed, including desks, chairs and books. With the #COVID19 pandemic and political insecurity further exacerbating the crisis, most children will be forced to remain out of school.

@unicef is on the ground delivering medical supplies, safe water and shelter for children and families, but additional funding will be needed to rebuild schools and continue the emergency response.

Regram: @unicef 

#ForEveryChild

node.text:
The #UnitedNations flag on display outside UN Headquarters in #NYC.

On Thursday's #WorldHumanitarianDay, we remember and honour our 22 colleagues who lost their lives when the UN in Baghdad was bombed on 19 August 2003.

"These women and men were killed carrying out the noblest of all human missions — the mission of peace," said UN Secretary-General @antonioguterres.

"On this day and every day, I have one clear message to humanitarians everywhere: Thank you. You deserve our deepest gratitude, admiration and appreciation, always."

We pay tribute to the brave men and women working to make the world a better place for everyone, often at great personal risk. We thank them for their courage and commitment. 

📸: UN Photo / Mark Garten

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Regram @antonioguterres:

Despite grave risks, humanitarian workers from the @UnitedNations and our partners put their lives on the line every day to deliver food, shelter and clean water, medicine and vaccines, protection, counselling and education. 

You can find them in Afghanistan, supporting Afghans as they enter a perilous new chapter in their country’s history. You can find them in Haiti, which suffered a devastating earthquake last week. From Yemen and Syria to Ethiopia, South Sudan, and beyond, humanitarians are staying and delivering. 

They have no political agenda. They are motivated only by the safety, human rights, dignity, and well-being of the people trapped by these emergencies. 
On this #WorldHumanitarianDay and every day, I have one clear message to humanitarians everywhere: Thank you. You deserve our deepest gratitude, admiration, and appreciation, always. 

As a global community, let’s honour humanitarians by re-committing to their safety and protection, no matter where they work. And let’s keep alive the flame of peace and hope in humanity that they hold in their hearts as they carry out their mission of peace in the most dangerous places on earth.

📸: Lebanon, 2020 (@unicef/Choufany); Mozambique, 2019 (@worldfoodprogramme); Guyana, 2021 (@refugees); Yemen 2019 (@un_ocha/Matteo Minasi)
